sections.content: I joined Rugiet Health as a full-stack engineer, but I found product management. This was the moment I realized my highest leverage wasn't writing codeâ€”it was asking the right questions before anyone wrote code.
The Paradox of Control: Saving Retention by Letting Users Go
Churn wasn't happening because users disliked the product. It was happening because they felt *trapped*. The rigid subscription model created anxiety.

sections.title: The Insight
sections.content: I analyzed user data and realized that patients were cancelling not because they wanted to leave, but because they needed a break (travel, surplus medication). Our system forced a binary choice: Stay or Quit. So they quit.

I championed a 'Pause' feature. Technically, this required refactoring our subscription state machine to support a 'suspended' status that preserved patient data without triggering billing events. It was a complex backend change, but it solved the psychological problem of 'subscription anxiety.'

sections.title: The Outcome
sections.content: Retention increased by 35%. By giving users the freedom to leave (temporarily), we gave them a reason to stay. It proved that in healthcare, *autonomy* is a key feature.
